I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam, through the Ministry of Health (MOH), requested that the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provide  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
strengthen implementation of the government’s flagship social health insurance (SHI) program. 
The SHI program aims to expand access to quality and affordable basic health care services, 
especially among the poor and marginalized groups. The TA is included in the ADB country 
operations business plan, 2017–2019 for Viet Nam.1 During the fact-finding mission (14–21 April 
2016), the government and ADB agreed on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost and financing arrangements, and terms of reference (TOR) for consultants.2 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Sustaining socioeconomic gains. Structural and market reforms since the 1986 Doi 
Moi (renovation) policy have enabled Viet Nam to achieve strong economic performance and 
social development outcomes. Formerly one of the poorest countries in Asia, Viet Nam has now 
attained lower-middle-income status. The poverty head count ratio fell from 60% in 1990 to 15% 
in 2010.3 The health of the Vietnamese people has improved significantly during the period 
2009–2013,4 which has contributed to the country’s socioeconomic gains. Viet Nam’s total 
health spending as a share of gross domestic product is now higher than that of other countries 
of similar or higher income in the region. The SHI program has become an important source of 
financing for health services, and is a key mechanism for improving equity in access to health 
care, and mitigating the risk of people falling into poverty due to excessive health care spending. 
A responsive SHI program is key to sustaining growth and promoting better living conditions. 
 
3.  Making social health insurance more responsive to health care needs. Viet Nam 
has adopted universal health coverage (UHC) as a national strategy, and has made significant 
progress in developing SHI as a mechanism for achieving UHC. Viet Nam’s SHI was initiated in 
1992 and the regulatory framework has been progressively strengthened to expand coverage, 
enforce compliance, and establish SHI funding mechanisms. The Law on Health Insurance 
(2008) created the national SHI program and established the goal of universal SHI coverage. 
The Master Plan for Universal Coverage, launched in 2012, seeks to reach 80% SHI coverage 
by 2020.5 The attainment of universal SHI coverage is enshrined in the Constitution of Viet Nam 
of 2013. The Law on Health Insurance was amended in 2014 to introduce enhancements such 
as family-based enrollment and a basic health service package.6 
 
4.  Several features of Viet Nam’s SHI program are considered good practice based on 
worldwide experience.7 The program has a single-payer health insurance system and a unified 
                                                
1  ADB. 2016. Country Operations Business Plan: Viet Nam, 2017–2019. Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website in 6 October 2016. 
3  World Bank. 2013. Poverty Reduction in Vietnam: Remarkable Progress, Emerging Challenges. 24 January. 
http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2013/01/24/poverty-reduction-in-vietnam-remarkable-progress-
emerging-challenges. 
4  Government of Viet Nam, MOH. 2014. Joint Annual Health Review, 2014: Strengthening Prevention and Control of 
Non-Communicable Diseases. Ha Noi. 
5  Government of Viet Nam, MOH. 2012. Master Plan for Universal Coverage from 2012–2015 and 2020. Ha Noi. 
6  Government of Viet Nam, The National Assembly. 2014. Amendments to the Law on Health Insurance (Law No. 
46/2014/QH13). Ha Noi. 
7  A. Somanathan, H.L. Dao, and T. V. Tien. 2013. Integrating the Poor into Universal Health Coverage in Vietnam. 
Universal Health Coverage Studies Series. No. 24. Washington, DC: World Bank.

2 
benefits package, and covered 76.5% of the population in 2015.8 There is a co-payment policy 
to manage service utilization, with exemptions and lower co-payment rates for the poor. Despite 
these achievements, interrelated policy and institutional constraints—pertaining to coverage, 
fragmentation, financing, risk pooling, the benefits package, provider payment mechanisms, and 
administration—have resulted in less-than-optimal performance of the SHI program. If SHI is to 
serve as a mechanism for achieving UHC, the policy and institutional framework needs to be 
evaluated, and policy actions identified to address these constraints. 
 
5.  Limited population coverage. SHI coverage increased significantly—from 10 million 
(13.4% of Viet Nam’s population) in 1999 to 69.9 million (76.5%) in 2015—but this left 21.5 
million people (23.5% of the population in 2015) uninsured, and unprotected from financial risk if 
they become sick. Full premium subsidies ensure nearly 100% coverage among the poor and 
ethnic minorities. In contrast, coverage of the near-poor remains low (55%) because these 
groups are  required to make partial contributions to premium costs, which many of them cannot 
afford.9 Coverage among groups who receive no premium subsidies—including informal sector 
workers and dependents of workers—is even lower (34%).10  
6.  Lack  of  financial  protection.  High  enrollment  rates  among  the  poor  and  ethnic 
minorities do not translate into effective coverage. Out-of-pocket spending, which was 49.4% of 
health care spending in 2013, limits the financial protection of vulnerable groups and is a key 
barrier that prevents them from accessing health services. High out-of-pocket costs are driven in 
part  by  fee-for-service  payment  mechanisms  and  hospital  autonomy  policies,  which  have 
created incentives for providers to increase the supply and cost of services in order to generate 
higher revenues. 
 
7.  The effectiveness of SHI is also affected by the single benefit package, which is the 
same for all beneficiaries, regardless of their specific health care requirements. Ensuring the 
SHI program is responsive to the needs of the elderly, who are expected to account for 26% of 
the population by 2050, presents a critical policy challenge. About 40% of the elderly population 
is not covered by SHI;11 many are poor and live in rural areas. Designing an appropriate benefit 
package for the elderly will increase their SHI coverage, and provide them with benefits in terms 
of both health and financial protection.  
 
8.  Equity  and  efficient  resource  use  in  the  SHI  program  are  undermined  by  negative 
externalities that stem from the mix of capitation and fee-for-service payment methods.12 The 
capitation system provides district hospitals with little incentive to refer patients to secondary 
and tertiary hospitals, because referral costs are deducted from the district hospital capitation 
package. This results in patients not receiving health care that is appropriate to their needs. 
                                                
8  Government of Viet Nam, Viet Nam Social Security. 2016. Report document in regular conference. 
9  Based on Decision Number 59/2015/QĐ-TTg dated 19 Nov 2015, “poor” refers to households with per capita 
monthly income below the poverty line (D900,000 in urban areas and D700,000 in rural areas) or households with 
per capita monthly income higher than the poverty line, and with 1/3 or more of the total score shortfall in access to 
basic social services; “near poor” refers to households with per capita monthly income higher than the poverty line, 
and with below 1/3 of the total score shortfall in access to basic social services. 
10  Government of Viet Nam, MOH. 2016. Health Financing Strategy of Viet Nam (2016–2025). Ha Noi. 
11  V. D. Dam. 2016. Speech delivered during the meeting with the Committee for the Elderly People. Ha Noi. 15 
March. 
12 Under the health insurance law, three types of provider payment methods can be applied: (i) capitation, which is 
used for primary health care and covers referral costs at secondary (provincial) and tertiary (central) hospitals for 
members registered at the district hospitals; (ii) fee-for-service, which is used in all secondary and tertiary hospitals 
and for referral health services, including high-cost services that are not paid by capitation; and (iii) payment by 
diagnosis-related group, which is being pilot tested in a few hospitals.

3 
Meanwhile, secondary and tertiary hospitals have little incentive to control costs, because they 
are paid on a fee-for-service basis, while the risk is absorbed by the district hospital. 
 
9.  The capitation-based payment method exacerbates the fragmentation of risk sharing 
and revenue pooling. Capitation rates for each membership group are calculated based on 
expenditure  patterns  in  a  given  province.  The  poor  and  near-poor  have  lower  hospital 
expenditures because of lower service utilization rates, which result from geographical and 
financial barriers to access health services, and a lack of knowledge of the SHI benefits they are 
entitled to. The lower expenditure among the poor and near-poor results in their capitation rate 
being significantly below the premium subsidy, meaning that in effect, the poor subsidize better-
off groups. At the provincial level, poorer provinces similarly subsidize richer provinces. District 
hospitals tend to limit their services within the capitation budget for each membership group, 
leading to underprovision of services to the poor because of their lower-value capitation rate. 
 
10.  Gaps in social health insurance financing. While the government’s contribution to SHI 
has increased since 2006, member contributions have declined.13 An increased public health 
budget is needed to expand the number of insured vulnerable groups with state-subsidized 
insurance premiums. However, public resource mobilization is constrained by low tax revenue 
collection. Expanding coverage based solely on membership contributions is very unlikely to 
succeed, because a significant proportion of those who are not enrolled are near-poor and/or 
informal sector workers. Collecting membership contributions from the informal sector, as well 
as the private formal sector, remains a challenge. The limited options for financing SHI coupled 
with inefficiencies in the allocation and use of SHI resources undermine the system’s long-term 
financial  sustainability.  Interventions  to  enhance  efficiency  need  to  be  complemented  with 
innovative financing mechanisms, such as the introduction of taxes on tobacco and alcohol. 
 
11.  Weak management and administrative capacity. Multiple ministries and organizations 
at  different  levels  are  assigned  with  SHI  management  and  administrative  responsibilities, 
causing gaps in capacity related to enrollment enforcement, contribution collections, claims 
management,  actuarial  analysis,  benefit  package  design,  and  establishment  of  payment 
mechanisms and remuneration rates.14 Differences in management structures and levels of 
authority between MOH and Viet Nam Social Security make communication and collaboration 
difficult. Internal fragmentation of SHI administration increases complexity and reduces the 
efficiency of SHI management. The institutional arrangements governing SHI must be reviewed 
and revised if UHC is to be achieved. Capacity building of SHI program stakeholders is needed 
to strengthen (i) program implementation through improved management and administration, 
and (ii) evidence-based policymaking through better policy analysis. 
 
12.  Link  to  ADB  strategy  and  operations.  The  TA  is  consistent  with  ADB  strategic 
priorities in the country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for Viet Nam.15 It is linked with the ADB 
Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020, which supports developing member countries in their 
efforts to attain UHC.16 ADB’s health strategy for Viet Nam aims to provide programmatic 
                                                
13  T.V. Tien, H.T. Phuong, I. Mathauer, and N. T. K. Phuong. 2011. A Health Financing Review of Viet Nam with a 
Focus  on  Health  Insurance:  Bottlenecks  in  Institutional  Design  and  Organizational  Practice  of  Health         
Financing  and  Options  to  Accelerate  Progress  Towards  Universal  Health  Coverage. 
http://www.who.int/health_financing/documents/oasis_f_11-vietnam.pdf?ua=1.  
14  A.  Somanathan  et  al.  2014.  Moving  Toward  Universal  Coverage  of  Social  Health  Insurance  in  Vietnam: 
Assessment and Options. Washington, DC: World Bank. 
15 ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Viet Nam, 2016–2020. Manila. 
16 ADB. 2015. Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020: Health in Asia and the Pacific–A Focused Approach to 
Address the Health Needs of ADB Developing Member Countries. Manila.

4 
support for achieving UHC through an improved regulatory and institutional SHI framework. It 
builds on ADB’s extensive health engagement in Viet Nam, including investments in pilot testing 
case-based funding mechanisms that support MOH’s work on provider payment reform.17 The 
TA will identify program opportunities for structural reforms in the health sector supporting UHC. 
13.  Development coordination. Development assistance to SHI has focused largely on 
analytical work and pilot testing of approaches to increase enrollment rates, reform provider 
payment methods, and design basic health service packages. The TA will build on prior analysis 
and  pilot  testing  by  focusing  on  core  policy  issues  critical  to  system  reform,  undertaking 
complementary research, and developing evidence-based policy reforms required to institute 
systemic change. Capacity building to strengthen SHI design and implementation will provide a 
foundation for further development assistance from ADB and other development partners. 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact will be universal SHI coverage achieved, which aligns with the Amendments 
to the Law on Health Insurance (2014) and the Master Plan for Universal Coverage. The 
outcome will be capacity of MOH and stakeholders enhanced to support the development and 
implementation of a responsive SHI program, especially for the poor and vulnerable people. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  Output 1: Priority legislative and regulatory measures identified and endorsed to 
appropriate authorities for decision. The TA will (i) support a review of the SHI program’s 
policy and institutional arrangements, including an assessment of the health insurance law, to 
analyze  operational  and  systemic  constraints  impeding  SHI  program  implementation;18  (ii) 
identify policy actions to address the constraints and support MOH in generating high-quality 
policy notes, position papers, and research to inform policy formulation; and (iii) help MOH 
develop a plan to enhance SHI’s regulatory and operational framework. The TA will engage 
experienced sector specialists to provide advice and analytical inputs on priority issues. Gender 
analysis will be a core part of the studies. Partnerships between MOH and educational or 
research institutions will be strengthened. A communications and advocacy plan will support the 
dissemination of policy briefs, research papers, and proposed regulatory reforms. 
 
16.  Output 2: Long-term health care model for the elderly designed and pilot tested. 
The TA will support the development of innovative solutions to address the long-term health 
care needs of the aging population. It will design and pilot a basic health services package for 
the elderly, with the aim of informing MOH’s broader efforts to develop a basic health services 
package to be covered by SHI. The pilot model will be designed in accordance with international 
good practices in long-term elderly health care and be informed by local surveys assessing the 
level and mix of health services provided to the elderly, and service and resource gaps. The 
pilot model will be evaluated in three provinces under varying socioeconomic, demographic, and 
service-use conditions; and its performance assessed against clinical, cost, and implementation 
efficacy indicators, and in terms of responsiveness to the needs of beneficiaries (female and 
male). Results will be documented and disseminated to inform evidence-based policy making. 
                                                
17 ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loans and 
Administration  of  Grant  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Health  Human  Resources  Sector 
Development Program. Manila. 
18 Priority policy issues will be determined at implementation in consultation with key stakeholders.

5 
 
17.  Output 3: Staff capacity and stakeholders’ knowledge of social health insurance 
improved.  The  TA  will  support  the  design  and  implementation  of  needs-based  capacity 
development  interventions  for  MOH  and  provincial  staff  to  enhance  their  professional 
competency in the areas of policy analysis, evidence-based policy making, health financing, and 
SHI implementation. The TA will conduct a staff learning needs assessment, with the results 
used to design and implement gender-sensitive competency-based training interventions for 
provincial and national staff. The TA will establish a system to track learning outcomes and the 
application of new skills by trainees. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,950,000 equivalent, of which $1,800,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, transportation costs, 
facilities for pilot testing, office accommodation and equipment, and other in-kind contributions. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOH will be the executing agency and will implement the TA under the supervision and 
guidance  of  the  health  minister.  MOH’s  Department  of  Health  Insurance  will  be  the 
implementing agency. Other implementing agencies may be identified during TA implementation, 
and may include other government agencies, provincial governments, educational and research 
institutions, and nongovernment organizations. The TA will be implemented from 1 January 
2017 to 31 December 2018. Knowledge, lessons, outputs, and outcome evaluation will be 
disseminated through workshops, publications, websites, and print and social media. 
 
20.  ADB will engage 9 person-months of international and 190 person-months of national 
consultant services. The consultant TOR are in Appendix 3. To maximize flexibility, the TOR 
and  selection  criteria  for  4  person-months  of  the  international  consulting  services  will  be 
determined during implementation. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with 
ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).19 The project 
management specialist will follow ADB Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to 
time)  in  procuring  equipment,  which  will  be  transferred  to  MOH  after  TA  completion.  The 
consultants will administer the activity costs related to the studies, workshops, training, and 
conferences, and prepare the TOR for resource persons. TA disbursements will follow the 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,800,000 to the Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for Strengthening the Policy and Institutional Framework of Social Health Insurance, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
19  The international consultants and national policy specialists will be recruited using the individual consultant 
selection method. Other national experts will be recruited through a firm using quality- and cost-based selection 
procedures with simplified technical proposals.

 Key Activities and Milestones 
 
1.  Priority legislative and regulatory measures identified and endorsed to appropriate 
authorities for decision 
1.1  Engage and mobilize experts and advisors (Q1 2017) 
1.2  Identify at least six priority policy issues to be analyzed (indicative topics include SHI premium, 
benefits package, administrative procedure for SHI examination and treatment, SHI cost 
reimbursement process, actuarial assessment on SHI financing for the medium and long term, 
primary health care provider registration and referral, SHI fund management, listing and procurement 
process for pharmaceuticals and medical devices, and containing pharmaceutical costs) (Q2 2017) 
1.3  Conduct 8 surveys, 39 consultation meetings, and 6 studies to inform the analysis of priority SHI 
policy issues, the review of the health insurance law, and the development of the SHI master plan 
(beginning Q2 2017) 
1.4  Complete policy analyses on at least six priority issues (Q4 2017–Q4 2018) 
1.5  Consolidate and endorse at least two sets of policy proposals for consideration by higher authorities 
(Q1 and Q4 2018) 
1.6  Formulate development policy matrix and medium-term expenditure program (Q4 2018) 
1.7  Develop and implement a policy advocacy and communications plan to disseminate the results of 
analytical work (beginning Q4 2017) 
1.8  Conduct eight workshops to present the findings from the analysis of six priority SHI policy issues, 
the review of the health insurance law, and development of the SHI master plan (beginning Q4 2018) 
1.9  Conduct six workshops to present findings from the six social research studies on priority SHI issues 
(beginning Q4 2018) 
 
2.  LTHC model for the elderly designed and pilot tested 
2.1  Engage and mobilize experts (Q2 2017) 
2.2  Conduct a survey and three consultation meetings to develop the LTHC model (Q3 2017) 
2.3  Develop selection criteria for participating provinces (Q3 2017) 
2.4  Conduct three preparatory training workshops for implementers of the LTHC pilot model (Q4 2017)

8  Appendix 1 
2.5  Conduct pilot program in three provinces (Q1 2018) 
2.6  Conduct three consultation meetings to evaluate the pilot and draft policy recommendations and 
circular for the LTHC model (Q3 2018) 
2.7  Conduct a workshop to present findings from the LTHC pilot and the draft policy recommendations 
(Q4 2018) 
 
3.  Staff capacity and stakeholders’ SHI knowledge improved 
3.1  Engage and mobilize experts (Q1 2017) 
3.2  Design and conduct annual capacity development needs assessment of MOH and LGU staff 
(beginning Q2 2017) 
3.3  Formulate the learning and development framework for MOH and LGU staff to enhance their policy 
development and implementation capacity (Q2 2017) 
3.4  Develop and use pre-and post-training tests to measure learning progress and outcomes of MOH 
and LGU staff (Q2 2017) 
3.5  Identify, organize, and begin implementing 29 capacity development workshops for MOH and LGU 
staff (Q3 2017) 
3.6  Monitor and report the results of capacity development interventions (Q3 2017) 
3.7  Design, develop, and implement a communications strategy for stakeholders (Q4 2017) 
3.8  Monitor and report outcomes of the implementation of a communications strategy for stakeholders 
and recommend appropriate actions (Q4 2018).

Note: The technical assistance (TA) is estimated to cost $1,950,000, of which contributions from the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction are presented in the table above. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart staff, transportation costs, facilities for pilot testing, office accommodation and equipment, and other in-
kind contributions. The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 7.7% of the total TA cost. The 
disbursement of funds will follow the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
a  Administered by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
b  Includes costs for translating reports. 
c  Includes  office  furniture,  desktop  computers,  notebooks,  a  multimedia  projector,  a  printer,  and  computer 
applications and programs. These will remain ADB’s property until disposed of or transferred to the government 
upon TA completion. Equipment will be procured following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from 
time to time). 
d  These will involve 2 workshops to present findings from the analysis of 6 priority social health insurance (SHI) 
policy issues, 1 workshop to present findings from the review of the health insurance law, 1 workshop to present 
findings from the development of the SHI master plan, 6 workshops to present findings from the 6 social research 
studies on priority SHI issues, 3 preparatory training workshops for implementers of the long-term health care 
(LTHC) pilot model, 1 workshop to present findings from the LTHC pilot and the draft policy recommendations, 24 
SHI training workshops for local government unit staff, and 5 SHI training courses for ministry staff. Workshops and 
training courses will be conducted at the provincial and central level. Consultants or external training facilitators will 
administer all workshops and training courses. 
e  Includes surveys and studies comprising (i) 6 surveys and 30 consultation meetings to inform the analysis of 6 
priority SHI policy issues, (ii) 1 survey and 5 consultation meetings to inform the review of the health insurance law, 
(iii) 1 survey and 4 consultation meetings to inform the development of the SHI master plan, (iv) 6 social research 
studies  on  priority  SHI  issues,  (v)  1  survey  and  3  consultation  meetings  to  design  the  LTHC  pilot,  (vi) 
implementation of the LTHC pilot study in 3 provinces, and (vii) 3 consultation meetings to evaluate the efficacy of 
the LTHC pilot model and prepare policy recommendations. Consultants will conduct all surveys and studies. 
f  Includes costs for information, education, and communication material production and public media campaign. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 9 person-months of international and 190 
person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  All  consultants  will  report  to  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and the Ministry of Health (MOH) of the Government of Viet Nam. To 
provide the TA with flexibility to mobilize expertise during implementation, the terms of reference 
(TOR) and selection criteria for 4 person-months of international consulting services—in long-
term  health  care  (LTHC)  and  learning  and  development—will  be  determined  during  TA 
implementation. The international consultants and national policy specialists will be recruited 
using the individual consultant selection method. Other national experts will be recruited through 
a firm using quality- and cost-based selection procedures with simplified technical proposals. 
A.  International Consultants 
2.  Health  insurance  policy  specialist  and  team  leader (1 expert, 5 person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist should have an advanced degree in public policy, health economics, 
or a related discipline; at least 15 years’ experience in policy development and research within 
the government and/or nongovernment sectors; relevant professional experience in Viet Nam; 
and an understanding of ADB processes and procedures. Experience in health financing policy 
is  desirable.  The  specialist  will  supervise  the  work  of  the  other  team  members  and  take 
responsibility for the following tasks in close consultation with MOH’s Department of Health 
Insurance (DHI) and other stakeholders: 
(i)  undertake overall management and coordination functions for the TA project; 
(ii)  provide guidance to DHI in defining the scope and focus of the studies; 
(iii)  provide guidance to the national policy specialists and national social research 
specialists on the study methodologies and frameworks; 
(iv)  participate in consultation meetings and provide a technical review of each study;  
(v)  collect and analyze gender-related information and data disaggregated by sex for 
the policy analyses and social research studies; 
(vi)  support  national  specialists  to  synthesize  findings  from  the  analysis  of  the 
studies, research, and reviews; 
(vii)  provide  technical  input  to  the  drafting  of  policy  briefs,  discussion  papers, 
circulars, and other documentation; 
(viii)  participate in advocacy and dissemination activities; 
(ix)  provide technical inputs to the development of a social health insurance (SHI) 
policy matrix and medium-term expenditure program; 
(x)  ensure timely submission of reports and outputs of all consultants engaged by 
the TA and oversee the preparation of TA progress and completion reports; and 
(xi)  complete any other tasks as may be reasonably requested by ADB or DHI. 
 
3.  Learning and development specialist (1 expert, 2 person-months, intermittent). The 
specialist’s  area  of  expertise  and  TOR  will  be  reconfirmed  and  formulated  during  TA 
implementation. 
 
4.  Long-term  health  care  specialist  (1  expert,  2  person-months,  continuous).  The 
specialist’s  area  of  expertise  and  TOR  will  be  reconfirmed  and  formulated  during  TA 
implementation.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  National Consultants 
5.  The national firm should have a relevant research background and/or experience in the 
social and health sectors (including laws and policies governing these sectors), with at least 3 
years of relevant experience working with development organizations such as ADB. Previous 
involvement in studies on Viet Nam’s SHI system would be an advantage. 
 
6.  Project  management  specialist  (1  expert,  24  person-months,  continuous).  The 
specialist should have an advanced degree in health management or a related discipline; at 
least 12 years of work experience in the health sector, with a minimum of 5 years of experience 
in the management of official development assistance projects; a demonstrated understanding 
of the policy and operational context of the SHI program; and familiarity with ADB procurement 
procedures. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  manage and oversee TA implementation in coordination with DHI; 
(ii)  represent the project in high-level meetings with MOH and with other relevant 
ministries and stakeholders; 
(iii)  collaborate with DHI and the international health insurance policy specialist to 
identify the priorities for health insurance policy issues, social research, and pilot 
testing and training activities; 
(iv)  oversee the scheduling of inputs by the project’s technical specialists; 
(v)  provide  management  support  to  national  specialists  in  the  organization  and 
delivery of all workshops, consultation meetings, and surveys; 
(vi)  undertake field monitoring to ensure the quality and timely completion of TA 
deliverables; 
(vii)  provide implementation support to local government units (LGUs) as required; 
(viii)  manage all procurement for the project following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2015, as amended from time to time); 
(ix)  under the direction of the team leader, ensure the timely submission of reports 
and outputs of all consultants engaged by the TA, and prepare TA progress and 
completion reports; and 
(x)  participate in review missions and coordination meetings as required. 
 
7.  Policy specialists (2 experts, 18 person-months each, intermittent). The specialists 
should  have  an  advanced  degree  in  health  economics,  health  management,  public 
administration, or a related discipline; at least 10 years of work experience in the health or social 
sector in Viet Nam; and extensive expertise in the policy area of interest demonstrated through 
publications in national and/or international spheres. The specialists will perform the following 
tasks: 
(i)  conduct  a  detailed  review  of  literature  within  and  outside  Viet  Nam  on  the 
specified priority health insurance policy issues; 
(ii)  conduct consultation meetings (five per policy issue) with policy makers and 
operational stakeholders from MOH, Viet Nam Social Security (VSS), LGUs, and 
other relevant government and nongovernment agencies; 
(iii)  design and implement surveys (one per policy issue) to collect field data to 
inform the policy analysis; 
(iv)  synthesize  findings  from  the  literature  and  stakeholder  analysis  to  prepare 
discussion  papers  and  policy  briefs  on  approaches  and  models  for 
implementation in the Viet Nam context, including an analysis of the opportunities 
and constraints associated with each approach and/or model; 
(v)  collect and analyze gender-related information and data disaggregated by sex for 
the policy analyses and social research studies;

12  Appendix 3 
(vi)  prepare a communications and advocacy plan for the dissemination of findings to 
relevant policy makers and sector stakeholders; 
(vii)  conduct one workshop to present findings from the analysis of three priority SHI 
policy issues to be considered by MOH; 
(viii)  conduct one workshop to present findings from the analysis of three priority SHI 
policy issues to be submitted to the Prime Minister or National Assembly; 
(ix)  conduct other dissemination and advocacy activities to facilitate the adoption of 
policy reforms; and 
(x)  provide inputs as required by the project’s planning specialist to the development 
of an SHI policy matrix and a medium-term expenditure program. 
 
8.  Social  research  specialists  (3  experts,  11  person-months  each,  intermittent).  The 
specialists  should  have  an  advanced  degree  in  social  sciences,  health  economics,  health 
management,  or  a  related  discipline;  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  the  design  and 
implementation  of  social  research;  and  demonstrated  experience  in  producing  high-quality 
discussion papers and policy notes. An understanding of the policy and operational context of 
the SHI program is desirable. The specialists will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  in collaboration with the project’s international health insurance policy specialist, 
design and implement six research studies to identify key operational constraints 
to the effective implementation of the SHI program; 
(ii)  synthesize research findings for discussion papers and policy briefs; 
(iii)  collect and analyze gender-related information and data disaggregated by sex for 
the policy analyses and social research studies; 
(iv)  conduct workshops (one per research study) to present findings from the six 
social research studies on priority SHI issues; 
(v)  participate in consultations with policy makers and operational stakeholders from 
MOH, VSS, LGUs, and other relevant government and nongovernment agencies 
as required to disseminate research findings; and 
(vi)  draw on research findings to provide recommendations to the health insurance 
law specialist’s review of the health insurance law and its associated operational 
circulars. 
 
9.  Gender specialist (1 expert, 6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should have 
an advanced degree in social sciences, gender and development, or a related discipline; at 
least 10 years of experience in gender development roles; demonstrated experience in the 
design and implementation of social research; and demonstrated experience in mainstreaming 
gender considerations in learning and development programs. The specialist will provide: 
(i)  technical input to the design of methodologies for policy analyses, social studies, 
and the LTHC pilot to ensure that gender considerations are addressed; 
(ii)  a technical review of the social studies and policy analyses to ensure that gender 
issues  have  been  appropriately  considered  in  the  synthesis  and 
recommendations; 
(iii)  technical input to the project’s learning and development activities, including the 
development of a gender-sensitive learning and development framework; and 
(iv)  technical  support  to  the  project  management  specialist  to  ensure  sex-
disaggregated monitoring and evaluation data is collected and reported. 
 
10.  Health  insurance  law  specialist  (1  expert,  6  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist should have an advanced degree in law, health economics, public administration, or a 
related discipline; at least 10 years of experience in health or social sector policy in Viet Nam; 
demonstrated understanding of the policy and operational context of the SHI program; and

Appendix 3  13 
demonstrated experience leading processes for legislative reform. The specialist will perform 
the following tasks: 
(i)  analyze  the  operational  constraints  affecting  the  effectiveness  of  the  SHI 
program, including population coverage, financing methods, benefit packages, 
provider payment mechanisms, and SHI administration; 
(ii)  undertake  a  detailed  review  of  the  health  insurance  law  and  its  associated 
polices  and  decisions  to  identify  regulatory  barriers  that  contribute  to  the 
operational constraints; 
(iii)  conduct consultation meetings with policy makers and operational stakeholders 
to identify required amendments to the health insurance law and its associated 
decrees and circulars to address the identified operational constraints; 
(iv)  design and implement a survey to collect field data to inform the analysis; 
(v)  synthesize  findings  from  the  review  of  the  legislation  and  stakeholder 
consultations to prepare policy briefs for the proposed amendments to the health 
insurance law; 
(vi)  conduct a workshop to present the findings from the detailed review of the health 
insurance law; 
(vii)  prepare draft revisions to the health insurance law and/or its associated decrees 
and circulars, as required; and 
(viii)  provide inputs as required by the project’s planning specialist to the development 
of a SHI policy matrix and medium-term expenditure program. 
 
11.  Planning  specialist (1 expert, 6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should 
have an advanced degree in health economics, health management, public administration, or a 
related discipline; at least 10 years of experience in health or social sector policy in Viet Nam; 
demonstrated understanding of the policy and operational context of the SHI program; and 
demonstrated experience in leading processes for health sector planning and policy reform. The 
specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  collaborate with stakeholders from MOH, VSS, and other agencies to undertake 
a review of past progress toward achieving targets for universal SHI coverage 
and the constraints to achieving these targets; 
(ii)  collaborate with the project’s policy specialists, social research specialists, and 
health insurance law specialist to identify the key areas for policy and operational 
reforms needed to achieve universal SHI; 
(iii)  conduct  four  consultation  meetings  with  sector  specialists  to  determine 
benchmarks  and  targets  for  the  regulatory,  operational,  financing,  and  other 
reforms required to progress to universal SHI coverage; 
(iv)  design and implement a survey to collect field data to inform the analysis; 
(v)  prepare a draft master plan toward universal SHI; 
(vi)  conduct a workshop to present the findings from the development of the SHI 
master plan and facilitate stakeholder review of the draft; and 
(vii)  lead the development of an SHI policy matrix and medium-term expenditure 
program with inputs from other international and national specialists. 
 
12.  Long-term  health  care  specialists  (1  expert to  support  design,  3  person-months, 
intermittent; 1 expert to support pilot testing, 6 person-months, intermittent; and 1 expert to 
support  the  production  of  circulars  for  the  models,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialists should have an advanced degree in health economics, public health policy, or a 
related discipline; at least 10 years of experience in health or the social sector, specializing in 
the  planning  of  aged  care  services;  and  demonstrated  understanding  of  the  policy  and 
operational context of the SHI program. The specialists will perform the following tasks:

14  Appendix 3 
(i)  identify  models  of  good  practices  in  health  care  services  and  SHI  payment 
packages for the elderly that are suitable for adaptation to the Viet Nam context; 
(ii)  conduct consultation meetings with stakeholders on the design of a pilot model 
for a health care service and SHI payment package for the elderly; 
(iii)  implement a survey to collect field data to inform the model design; 
(iv)  develop the pilot model design, including criteria for selecting pilot locations; 
(v)  conduct three training workshops (one per province) on the LTHC model for 
implementation stakeholders; 
(vi)  oversee the field implementation of the pilot, including the provision of technical 
support during implementation; 
(vii)  synthesize key findings from the pilot into discussion papers and policy briefs to 
inform decisions on SHI policy reform for the implementation of a responsive 
benefits package for the elderly; and 
(viii)  present the findings from the LTHC pilot and the draft policy recommendations. 
 
13.  Information  education  communication  specialist  (1  expert,  6  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist should have an advanced degree in communications, public health, 
or a related discipline; at least 10 years of experience in the design and implementation of 
communications programs in the health or social sectors; and demonstrated experience in the 
design  of  communications  materials  and  public  media  campaigns  targeting  ethnic  minority 
audiences. The specialist will: 
(i)  prepare communications materials for key target audiences, including the rural 
poor and ethnic minority populations, on select topics related to the proposed 
operational reforms for achieving universal SHI coverage; 
(ii)  pre-test materials with target audiences and incorporate feedback into material 
design; 
(iii)  provide technical support to provincial agencies responsible for the design and 
delivery of the public media campaign; and 
(iv)  prepare a communications and advocacy plan to disseminate findings from the 
policy review to stakeholders. 
 
14.  Learning and development specialist (1 expert, 12 person-months, intermittent). The 
specialist should have an advanced degree in human resource development, adult training, 
social  sciences,  or  a  related  discipline;  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  the  delivery, 
management, and monitoring of training programs; and demonstrated experience in the design 
of a results-based learning curriculum. The specialist will: 
(i)  design and conduct capacity development needs assessments; 
(ii)  prepare a learning and development framework to guide capacity strengthening; 
(iii)  develop training syllabus and curriculum for the training workshops; 
(iv)  organize and oversee the implementation of training workshops; and 
(v)  monitor and measure learning progress and outcomes. 
 
15.  Project assistants (2 consultants, 24 person-months each, continuous). The assistants 
will  provide  administrative  and  coordination  support  to  DHI  and  the  project  management 
specialist  to  ensure  the  timely  and  efficient  project  implementation.  The  project  assistants 
should have a degree in management, administration, or a related discipline, and at least 5 
years of work experience in administrative roles within the health sector. Previous experience as 
a project assistant for official development assistance projects is desirable.
